tp:docstring.p: An interface for providing debug messages.
This interface is primarily provided by one object per service, at the path /org/freedesktop/Telepathy/debug.

property.name: Enabled
property.tp:docstring: TRUE if the NewDebugMessage signal should be emitted when a new debug message is generated.

method.name: GetMessages
method.tp:docstring: Retrieve buffered debug messages. An implementation could have a limit on how many message it keeps and so the array returned from this method should not be assumed to be all of the messages in the lifetime of the service.

arg.name: Messages
arg.tp:docstring: A list of debug messages.

signal.name: NewDebugMessage
signal.tp:docstring: Emitted when a debug messages is generated if the Enabled property is set to TRUE.

arg.name: time
arg.tp:docstring: Timestamp of the debug message.

arg.name: domain
arg.tp:docstring: Domain of the debug message, as described in the Debug_Message struct.

arg.name: level
arg.tp:docstring: Level of the debug message.

arg.name: message
arg.tp:docstring: The text of the debug message.

tp:enumvalue.tp:docstring: Log level for errors. Error messages are always fatal, resulting in the service terminating after something completely unexpected occurred.
Log level for critical messages. Critical messages are messages that the service might predict and it is up to the service itself to decide whether to terminate following a critical message.
Log level for warnings.
Log level for messages.
Log level for information messages.
Log level for debug messages.

tp:struct.name: Debug_Message
tp:struct.tp:docstring: A struct representing a debug message, as returned by GetMessages.

tp:member.name: Timestamp
tp:member.tp:docstring: Timestamp of the debug message. This is a double to allow more accuracy in the time the message was logged.

tp:docstring.p: Domain of the debug message. This is used to identify the source of debug messages. For example, debug messages from a connection manager could have this Domain struct member be the name of the connection manager, and logs from any helper library could have the name of the helper library.

The domain could also contain a category as to where the log message originated separated by a forward-slash. For example, if a debug message was output in a connection manager called "dummy", in the file-transfer code, this Domain struct member might be dummy/file-transfer.

tp:member.name: Level
tp:member.tp:docstring: Level of the debug message. This states the severity of the debug message.

tp:member.name: Message
tp:member.tp:docstring: The text of the debug message.

tp:simple-type.name: Unix_Timestamp
tp:simple-type.tp:docstring: An unsigned 32-bit integer representing time as the number of seconds elapsed since the Unix epoch (1970-01-01T00:00:00Z)

tp:simple-type.name: Unix_Timestamp64
tp:simple-type.tp:docstring: An signed 64-bit integer representing time as the number of seconds elapsed since the Unix epoch (1970-01-01T00:00:00Z); negative for times before the epoch
tp:simple-type.tp:rationale: The Text interface is the only user of Unix_Timestamp so far, and we'd like to be Y2038 compatible in future interfaces.

tp:simple-type.name: DBus_Bus_Name
tp:simple-type.tp:docstring: A string representing a D-Bus bus name - either a well-known name like "org.freedesktop.Telepathy.MissionControl" or a unique name like ":1.123"

tp:simple-type.name: DBus_Well_Known_Name
tp:simple-type.tp:docstring: A string representing a D-Bus well-known name like "org.freedesktop.Telepathy.MissionControl".

tp:simple-type.name: DBus_Unique_Name
tp:simple-type.tp:docstring: A string representing a D-Bus unique name, such as ":1.123"

tp:simple-type.name: DBus_Interface
tp:simple-type.tp:docstring: An ASCII string representing a D-Bus interface - two or more elements separated by dots, where each element is a non-empty string of ASCII letters, digits and underscores, not starting with a digit. The maximum total length is 255 characters. For example, "org.freedesktop.DBus.Peer".

tp:simple-type.name: DBus_Error_Name
tp:simple-type.tp:docstring: An ASCII string representing a D-Bus error. This is syntactically the same as a DBus_Interface, but the meaning is different.

tp:simple-type.name: DBus_Signature
tp:simple-type.tp:docstring: A string representing a D-Bus signature (the 'g' type isn't used because of poor interoperability, particularly with dbus-glib)

tp:simple-type.name: DBus_Member
tp:simple-type.tp:docstring: An ASCII string representing a D-Bus method, signal or property name - a non-empty string of ASCII letters, digits and underscores, not starting with a digit, with a maximum length of 255 characters. For example, "Ping".

tp:simple-type.name: DBus_Qualified_Member
tp:simple-type.tp:docstring: A string representing the full name of a D-Bus method, signal or property, consisting of a DBus_Interface, followed by a dot, followed by a DBus_Member. For example, "org.freedesktop.DBus.Peer.Ping".

tp:mapping.name: Qualified_Property_Value_Map
tp:mapping.tp:docstring: A mapping from strings representing D-Bus properties (by their namespaced names) to their values.

tp:member.name: Key
tp:member.tp:docstring: A D-Bus interface name, followed by a dot and a D-Bus property name.

tp:member.name: Value
tp:member.tp:docstring: The value of the property.

tp:mapping.name: String_Variant_Map
tp:mapping.tp:docstring: A mapping from strings to variants representing extra key-value pairs.

tp:mapping.name: String_String_Map
tp:mapping.tp:docstring: A mapping from strings to strings representing extra key-value pairs.

tp:struct.name: Socket_Address_IP
tp:struct.tp:docstring: An IP address and port.

tp:member.name: Address
tp:member.tp:docstring: Either a dotted-quad IPv4 address literal as for Socket_Address_IPv4, or an RFC2373 IPv6 address as for Socket_Address_IPv6.

tp:member.name: Port
tp:member.tp:docstring: The TCP or UDP port number.

tp:struct.name: Socket_Address_IPv4
tp:struct.tp:docstring: An IPv4 address and port.

tp:member.name: Address
tp:member.tp:docstring: A dotted-quad IPv4 address literal: four ASCII decimal numbers, each between 0 and 255 inclusive, e.g. "192.168.0.1".

tp:member.name: Port
tp:member.tp:docstring: The TCP or UDP port number.

tp:struct.name: Socket_Address_IPv6
tp:struct.tp:docstring: An IPv6 address and port.

tp:member.name: Address
tp:member.tp:docstring: An IPv6 address literal as specified by RFC2373 section 2.2, e.g. "2001:DB8::8:800:200C:4171".

tp:member.name: Port
tp:member.tp:docstring: The TCP or UDP port number.

tp:struct.name: Socket_Netmask_IPv4
tp:struct.tp:docstring: An IPv4 network or subnet.

tp:member.name: Address
tp:member.tp:docstring: A dotted-quad IPv4 address literal: four ASCII decimal numbers, each between 0 and 255 inclusive, e.g. "192.168.0.1".

tp:member.name: Prefix_Length
tp:member.tp:docstring: The number of leading bits of the address that must match, for this netmask to be considered to match an address.

tp:struct.name: Socket_Netmask_IPv6
tp:struct.tp:docstring: An IPv6 network or subnet.

tp:member.name: Address
tp:member.tp:docstring: An IPv6 address literal as specified by RFC2373 section 2.2, e.g. "2001:DB8::8:800:200C:4171".

tp:member.name: Prefix_Length
tp:member.tp:docstring: The number of leading bits of the address that must match, for this netmask to be considered to match an address.

tp:error.name: Network Error
tp:error.tp:docstring: Raised when there is an error reading from or writing to the network.

tp:error.name: Not Implemented
tp:error.tp:docstring: Raised when the requested method, channel, etc is not available on this connection.

tp:error.name: Invalid Argument
tp:error.tp:docstring: Raised when one of the provided arguments is invalid.

tp:error.name: Not Available
tp:error.tp:docstring: Raised when the requested functionality is temporarily unavailable.

tp:error.name: Permission Denied
tp:error.tp:docstring: The user is not permitted to perform the requested operation.

tp:error.name: Disconnected
tp:error.tp:docstring:
The connection is not currently connected and cannot be used. This error may also be raised when operations are performed on a Connection for which StatusChanged has signalled status Disconnected for reason None.
The second usage corresponds to None in the Connection_Status_Reason enum; if a better reason is available, the corresponding error should be used instead.

tp:error.name: Invalid Handle
tp:error.tp:docstring: The handle specified is unknown on this channel or connection.

tp:error.name: Channel.Banned
tp:error.tp:docstring: You are banned from the channel.

tp:error.name: Channel.Full
tp:error.tp:docstring: The channel is full.

tp:error.name: Channel.Invite Only
tp:error.tp:docstring: The requested channel is invite-only.

tp:docstring.p: The requested channel or other resource already exists, and another user interface in this session is responsible for it.
User interfaces SHOULD handle this error unobtrusively, since it indicates that some other user interface is already processing the channel.

tp:error.name: Cancelled
tp:error.tp:docstring:
Raised by an ongoing request if it is cancelled by user request before it has completed, or when operations are performed on an object which the user has asked to close (for instance, a Connection where the user has called Disconnect, or a Channel where the user has called Close).
The second form can be used to correspond to the Requested member in the Connection_Status_Reason enum, or to to represent the situation where disconnecting a Connection, closing a Channel, etc. has been requested by the user but this request has not yet been acted on, for instance because the service will only act on the request when it has finished processing an event queue.

tp:error.name: Authentication Failed
tp:error.tp:docstring:
Raised when authentication with a service was unsuccessful.
This corresponds to Authentication_Failed in the Connection_Status_Reason enum.

tp:error.name: Encryption Not Available
tp:error.tp:docstring:
Raised if a user request insisted that encryption should be used, but encryption was not actually available.
This corresponds to part of Encryption_Error in the Connection_Status_Reason enum. It's been separated into a distinct error here because the two concepts that were part of EncryptionError seem to be things that could reasonably appear differently in the UI.

tp:error.name: Encryption Error
tp:error.tp:docstring:
Raised if encryption appears to be available, but could not actually be used (for instance if SSL/TLS negotiation fails).
This corresponds to part of Encryption_Error in the Connection_Status_Reason enum.

tp:error.name: Cert.Not Provided
tp:error.tp:docstring:
Raised if the server did not provide a SSL/TLS certificate. This error MUST NOT be used to represent the absence of a client certificate provided by the Telepathy connection manager.
This corresponds to Cert_Not_Provided in the Connection_Status_Reason enum. That error explicitly applied only to server SSL certificates, so this one is similarly limited; having the CM present a client certificate is a possible future feature, but it should have its own error handling.

tp:error.name: Cert.Untrusted
tp:error.tp:docstring:
Raised if the server provided a SSL/TLS certificate signed by an untrusted certifying authority. This error SHOULD NOT be used to represent a self-signed certificate: see the Self Signed error for that.
This corresponds to Cert_Untrusted in the Connection_Status_Reason enum, with a clarification to avoid ambiguity.

tp:error.name: Cert.Expired
tp:error.tp:docstring:
Raised if the server provided an expired SSL/TLS certificate.
This corresponds to Cert_Expired in the Connection_Status_Reason enum.

tp:error.name: Cert.Not Activated
tp:error.tp:docstring:
Raised if the server provided an SSL/TLS certificate that will become valid at some point in the future.
This corresponds to Cert_Not_Activated in the Connection_Status_Reason enum.

tp:error.name: Cert.Fingerprint Mismatch
tp:error.tp:docstring:
Raised if the server provided an SSL/TLS certificate that did not have the expected fingerprint.
This corresponds to Cert_Fingerprint_Mismatch in the Connection_Status_Reason enum.

tp:error.name: Cert.Hostname Mismatch
tp:error.tp:docstring:
Raised if the server provided an SSL/TLS certificate that did not match its hostname.
This corresponds to Cert_Hostname_Mismatch in the Connection_Status_Reason enum.

tp:error.name: Cert.Self Signed
tp:error.tp:docstring:
Raised if the server provided an SSL/TLS certificate that is self-signed and untrusted.
This corresponds to Cert_Hostname_Mismatch in the Connection_Status_Reason enum.

tp:error.name: Cert.Invalid
tp:error.tp:docstring:
Raised if the server provided an SSL/TLS certificate that is unacceptable in some way that does not have a more specific error.
This corresponds to Cert_Other_Error in the Connection_Status_Reason enum.

tp:error.name: Not Capable
tp:error.tp:docstring: Raised when requested functionality is unavailable due to contact not having required capabilities.

tp:error.name: Offline
tp:error.tp:docstring:
Raised when requested functionality is unavailable because a contact is offline.
This corresponds to Offline in the Channel_Group_Change_Reason enum.

tp:error.name: Channel.Kicked
tp:error.tp:docstring:
Used to represent a user being ejected from a channel by another user, for instance being kicked from a chatroom.
This corresponds to Kicked in the Channel_Group_Change_Reason enum.

tp:error.name: Busy
tp:error.tp:docstring:
Used to represent a user being removed from a channel because of a "busy" indication. This error SHOULD NOT be used to represent a server or other infrastructure being too busy to process a request - for that, see ServerBusy.
This corresponds to Busy in the Channel_Group_Change_Reason enum.

tp:error.name: No Answer
tp:error.tp:docstring:
Used to represent a user being removed from a channel because they did not respond, e.g. to a StreamedMedia call.
This corresponds to No_Answer in the Channel_Group_Change_Reason enum.

tp:error.name: Does Not Exist
tp:error.tp:docstring:
Raised when the requested user does not, in fact, exist.
This corresponds to Invalid_Contact in the Channel_Group_Change_Reason enum, but can also be used to represent other things not existing (like chatrooms, perhaps).

tp:error.name: Terminated
tp:error.tp:docstring:
Raised when a channel is terminated for an unspecified reason. In particular, this error SHOULD be used whenever normal termination of a 1-1 StreamedMedia call by the remote user is represented as a D-Bus error name.
This corresponds to None in the Channel_Group_Change_Reason enum.

tp:error.name: Connection Refused
tp:error.tp:docstring: Raised when a connection is refused.

tp:error.name: Connection Failed
tp:error.tp:docstring: Raised when a connection can't be established.

tp:error.name: Connection Lost
tp:error.tp:docstring: Raised when a connection is broken.

tp:error.name: Already Connected
tp:error.tp:docstring:
Raised when the user attempts to connect to an account but they are already connected (perhaps from another client or computer), and the protocol or account settings do not allow this.
XMPP can have this behaviour if the user chooses the same resource in both clients (it is server-dependent whether the result is AlreadyConnected on the new connection, ConnectionReplaced on the old connection, or two successful connections).

tp:error.name: Connection Replaced
tp:error.tp:docstring:
Raised by an existing connection to an account if it is replaced by a new connection (perhaps from another client or computer).
In MSNP, when connecting twice with the same Passport, the new connection "wins" and the old one is automatically disconnected. XMPP can also have this behaviour if the user chooses the same resource in two clients (it is server-dependent whether the result is AlreadyConnected on the new connection, ConnectionReplaced on the old connection, or two successful connections).

tp:error.name: Registration Exists
tp:error.tp:docstring: Raised during in-band registration if the server indicates that the requested account already exists.

tp:error.name: Service Busy
tp:error.tp:docstring:
Raised if a server or some other piece of infrastructure cannot process the request, e.g. due to resource limitations. Clients MAY try again later.
This is not the same error as Busy, which indicates that a user is busy.

tp:error.name: Resource Unavailable
tp:error.tp:docstring:
Raised if a request cannot be satisfied because a process local to the user has insufficient resources. Clients MAY try again later.
For instance, the ChannelDispatcher might raise this error for some or all channel requests if it has detected that there is not enough free memory.
